title: Overall [0–9]
stimulusHtml:
9 points

The intent of this question was to test students’ ability to aurally analyze and then notate in treble clef a melody in compound meter and melodic minor. The melody contains both steps and skips, dotted rhythms, chromatic alteration, and the raised 6th and 7th scale degrees. The mean score was 3.15 out of a possible 9 points.

Always begin with the regular scoring guide. Try an alternate guide only if necessary. (See I.4.)

I. Regular Scoring Guide

  1. Award 1 point for each half-measure correct in both pitch and rhythm.

    • A “half-measure” is any set of three contiguous eighth-note beats of the original melody, even if occurring over a barline or beginning on a metrically weak pulse.

    • A half-measure is also known as a “segment.”

    • To receive credit, a segment must not overlap with any other segment receiving credit.

    • To receive credit, a segment may be metrically shifted from its original position.

    • Give no credit for the final dotted quarter note if notation of pitches continues thereafter.

  2. If at least one segment is correct in pitch and rhythm, add 1 point to the total. For example, a response that is correct in all aspects receives a score of 8 + 1, or 9. Exception: Do not award a 9 unless all measures have the correct number of beats. Award an 8 (i.e., do not award the extra point) to an otherwise perfect paper that does not use barlines correctly.

  3. Record any score of 4 or higher and move to the next book. (In this case, ignore the alternate guides.)

  4. If after applying I.1. and I.2., the score is less than 4, try an alternate scoring guide.

II. Alternate Scoring Guides (Do not add the extra point to the total.)

  1. Award 1/2 point per half-measure of correct pitches. (Maximum of 4 points.)
    OR

  2. Award 1/4 point per half-measure of correct rhythm. (Maximum of 2 points.)

III. Rounding Fractional Scores

  1. Half-point totals should be rounded down with one exception: a total score of 1½ should be rounded up to 2.

  2. Quarter points should be rounded to the closest integer.

IV. Scores with Additional Meaning

1 This score may also be used for responses that have less than one half-measure correct in both pitch and rhythm but that have two or more redeeming qualities. (Do not add the extra point!)

0 A response that demonstrates an attempt to answer the question but that has no redeeming qualities (or only one).

V. Notes

  1. No enharmonic equivalents or octave transpositions are permitted.

  2. If you use an alternate scoring guide, do not add the extra point to the total.

  3. If you try both regular and alternate scoring guides, record the higher of the scores if there is a difference.

  4. Scores from one guide may not be combined with those from another guide.
